about/this-site.html.title: THIS SITE
about/this-site.html.description:
Even this website is something interesting to talk about - at least to me.For the past 6 months or so I've been fairly enamored with using LLMs to build (mostly) software stuff. I've always enjoyed building things in the world of general internet-related technologies, and for the last half of my professional career I was either building, supporting, or monitoring enterprise tooling and platforms across several industries.I always enjoyed stumbling across a nice batteries-included tutorial to build some cool thing in docker, or some vendors detailed installation for their community-edition or self-hosted option.I, early-on, installed a proxmox server in my basement, and used portainer to make building platforms and docker-based applications super convenient.But now, using LLMs that are aware, by definition, of how everything is built and how they work, dynamic and mostly right tutorials are at our fingertips for ANYTHING - and simply by asking for it.
This site is constructed in Obsidian, and using an Obsidian plug-in written, coincidentally, by a fellow I know from the lab I am involved with at UofL, Nathan George, the Obsidian vault containing these pages can be exported as a complete website.Once the pages are exported locally, a typical static site publishing workflow is used to: make updates to a repo push that repo to github use github pages to 'publish' those pages to a publicly accessible URL
Here is that repo and here is an explanation / setup page I asked Claude to write for me when I was done.

projects/why-this.html.title: WHY THIS
projects/why-this.html.description:
I basically organize everything I do in these buckets called Projects. Home Projects, Fun Projects, Hobby Projects, School Stuff Masquerading As Projects, etc.It's just simpler, and something I adopted while doing software projects - everything is a project that doesn't have a more logical grouping construct (which does exist - Classes, for example). Then I adopted it when doing formal LLM-assist stuff.My ~/projects folder:Claudsidian is a concept I made up which is loosely using Obsdian and Claude together in some manner.
My Claudsidian folder :

projects/iths/curation/discussion-01.htm.title: discussion-01
projects/iths/curation/discussion-01.htm.description:
A working discussion space for figuring out how the ITHS Curation Committee should approach: Defining the structure of an ontology for IT historical artifacts, people, and relationships Translating that ontology into a database architecture Running the process collaboratively as a group (not just technically) An ontology for a historical society isn't just a schema. It's a set of claims about what kinds of things exist, how they relate, and what the organization believes is worth tracking. Before touching any database tool, the committee needs to answer questions like: What is the primary unit of record? (An artifact? A product line? A company? A person? An event?) What does "historical significance" mean for this organization? (Who decides? By what criteria?) How do we model influence and lineage? ("X led to Y" is a relationship, but there are many kinds of causality) What is the boundary between canonical record and user contribution? These are editorial and philosophical questions, not technical ones. The database follows from the answers.These examples are chosen because they faced the same core challenge: a community needed to agree on what things are before they could build anything.The Getty Research Institute maintains three controlled vocabularies — the Art & Architecture Thesaurus (AAT), the Union List of Artist Names (ULAN), and the Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN). These are among the most mature cultural heritage ontologies in existence.Relevance to ITHS: They separate concept records (what a thing is, abstractly) from instance records (a specific object or person) ULAN explicitly models relationships between artists: teacher/student, collaborator, influenced-by The AAT has a formal process for community submissions and editorial review — this maps well to the "canonical vs. user submission" problem Key lesson: They started with use cases, not with schema. "What questions do curators actually ask?" drove the structure.Reference: getty.edu/research/tools/vocabulariesWikidata is a general-purpose, community-maintained knowledge graph that underlies much of Wikipedia's structured data. Everything is a statement about an item, with properties and qualifiers.Relevance to ITHS: It explicitly handles the "X influenced Y" problem via properties like influenced by, has part, follows, followed by It has a clean separation between the item (canonical) and references (sourced claims) It's entirely open and the data model documentation is excellent for learning how to think about these problems Key lesson: Their data model evolved through community consensus via "WikiProjects" — groups that decided on the properties and structure for a domain (e.g., WikiProject Video Games, WikiProject Computing). This is a direct model for how the ITHS committee could work.
Reference: wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:WikiProjectsThe CHM has an online collection catalog that models hardware, software, people, and corporate history. They've had to solve the same "what is a canonical item?" question — is the canonical item the product design, the specific manufactured unit, or the product line?Relevance to ITHS: Their distinction between artifact (a physical thing), object type (a class of thing), and lot (a collection) maps onto the ITHS problem of personal submissions vs. canonical records They use a controlled vocabulary for significance/impact categories Key lesson: They distinguish "what the object is" from "what the object means" — physical description is separated from historical narrative. This prevents the ontology from collapsing under the weight of interpretation.
Reference: computerhistory.org/collections/Rick Prelinger's film archive and the broader Internet Archive have grappled with how to describe media items that have complex provenance chains — one film might be a copy of a copy, with annotations added by multiple hands.Relevance to ITHS: The "user submits their copy or story of a canonical item" feature is essentially a provenance and versioning problem Dublin Core and Schema.org (which IA uses heavily) are good prior art for simple, flat metadata that is still interoperable Key lesson: Don't invent what already exists. Dublin Core, Schema.org, and SKOS cover a huge amount of the basic metadata and relationship vocabulary. Start by mapping your concepts to these before creating custom properties.Open Library models the same three-tier structure that ITHS likely needs:Key lesson: This hierarchy is well-understood and worth adopting directly. It cleanly separates the abstract thing from its instantiations.
Reference: openlibrary.org/developers/apiBased on the above examples, here is a rough sequence for how the committee might work:Before any data modeling, collect 10–15 concrete questions that the database should be able to answer. Examples: "What hardware innovations came out of Xerox PARC and what products did they influence?" "Show me a timeline of storage media from punch cards to SSDs" "Who were the key engineers at DEC and what did they go on to build?" "What members have submitted photos of Apple I machines?" These become the test cases for the ontology. If a proposed schema can't answer them, it's incomplete.Working from the use cases, list the types of things and types of relationships that appear. Don't worry about the database yet. A whiteboard or a simple document is fine.Entity types might include: Person, Organization, Product, ProductLine, Concept/Innovation, Event, Document/Publication, PhysicalArtifact (user submission).Relationship types might include: EmployedBy, InventedBy, InfluencedBy, PrecededBy, PartOf, VersionOf, ContributedTo.Before designing custom schema, check if Schema.org, Wikidata properties, or the Getty AAT already have the concept. This saves time and enables future interoperability.Write entity definitions and relationship definitions in plain sentences before touching any technical notation. Example: A Product is a commercially released item (hardware or software) with a known manufacturer and release date. A Product may have a PrecededBy relationship to another Product if the earlier Product was a direct technical or commercial predecessor. Pick one domain (e.g., personal computers from 1975–1985) and build the schema for just that slice. Load a small amount of real data. See what breaks.Only after Phases 1–5 is it worth deciding: relational, graph, or hybrid? Document store? The answer should fall out of the data naturally, not be chosen up front. What is the minimum viable set of entity types to launch with? Who has editorial authority over canonical records vs. user submissions? Is the goal a public-facing database, an internal curatorial tool, or both? What existing databases (Wikidata, CHM catalog) should we link to rather than duplicate? How do we handle contested history? (Competing claims of "who invented X") Share this doc with the committee for feedback Schedule a use-case collection session (Phase 1) Identify which committee members have worked with any of the reference systems above Look at the existing Drupal 7 database schema — what entities does it already have?

projects/iths/general/this-is-it.html.title: this is IT
projects/iths/general/this-is-it.html.description:
Approaches and suggestions for defining Information TechnologyRestricting IT to computers is a common but historically shallow framing. It ignores the decades of foundational work that made computing possible — and the broader truth that information, not hardware, is the subject. The better question is: what does IT do? It captures, processes, stores, transmits, and retrieves information. The machinery changes; the mission doesn't.Define IT by what it does, not what it is made of:
Any technology whose primary purpose is to handle information — acquiring, storing, processing, transmitting, or displaying it.
This immediately includes:
Telegraphs and telephone switches
Radio and television broadcasting infrastructure
Punch card systems (pre-electronic)
Modern computing, networking, and AI
Why this works: It's technology-agnostic and future-proof. When something new arrives (quantum computing, biological computing), you can ask "does it handle information?" rather than "does it look like a computer?"Trace IT back to its intellectual origins rather than its commercial ones.Key waypoints:
1840s — Telegraph: the first system to separate information from a physical carrier (the message from the messenger)
1876 — Telephone: real-time voice as data
Bell Labs (1920s–1970s) — Transistor, information theory, Shannon's entropy, error correction, signal processing. This is arguably the true birthplace of modern IT
1948 — Claude Shannon's A Mathematical Theory of Communication — the foundational paper that defines information mathematically and underpins all digital systems
1950s–60s — Mainframe computing emerges from this lineage, not apart from it
1970s–present — Personal computing, internet, mobile, cloud
The takeaway: computers didn't create IT; IT created computers. The field existed before the transistor.Information technology is a subset of the broader field of information science, which includes:
How information is structured and classified (library science, ontologies, metadata)
How it is communicated (linguistics, semiotics, media studies)
How it is secured and controlled (cryptography, policy)
How it is used by humans (HCI, cognitive science)
This approach connects IT to disciplines that don't typically appear in a CS curriculum but are inseparable from it in practice. Cybersecurity, UX, data governance, and AI ethics all live here.IT doesn't exist in isolation — it's always embedded in social systems. Defining it purely as hardware or software misses the human layer.
IT is the ensemble of tools, practices, standards, and institutions that societies use to manage information.
This includes:
Postal systems (organised information routing)
Filing and records management
Standards bodies (IEEE, IETF, ISO) — the "invisible infrastructure"
Data centres as physical/social infrastructure
Why this is useful for teaching: It prevents students from thinking of IT as purely technical, which helps when addressing ethics, policy, and real-world impact.For a more rigorous framing: information, in the technical sense, is reduction of uncertainty. IT is any system that does this systematically.A traffic light is a rudimentary IT system. A spreadsheet is an IT system. So is a filing cabinet. What makes modern IT distinctive is:
Scale (billions of operations, billions of users)
Speed (real-time or near-real-time)
Programmability (the system can be reconfigured without physical change)
This framing lets you distinguish IT from other technologies while explaining why electronics and software became central — they maximise all three properties.Rather than one rigid definition, consider a layered scope:The "core" is what most people mean by IT in everyday use. The outer layers are what separate a practitioner from a technician. Open with Bell Labs — it's one of the most productive research environments in history and draws a direct line from physics → information theory → computing → the internet. It immediately challenges the "IT = computers" assumption. Use Shannon's definition of information as an early anchor. It's rigorous, non-circular, and gives students a durable mental model that survives technological change. Include one non-digital case study (e.g., the London postal system in the 1800s, or telephone exchange operators) to demonstrate that information systems predate electronics. Frame computers as an instantiation of IT, not its definition — the way an internal combustion engine is one instantiation of the idea of a heat engine. Acknowledge the fuzzy boundary — IT overlaps with electrical engineering, communications, media, and management. That's not a weakness; it's evidence that information is genuinely central to modern life. Document created: 2026-02-26

headers.heading: Suggested Scope for a Working Definition

projects/iths/general/what-is-it.html.title: what is IT
projects/iths/general/what-is-it.html.description: There may be an issue actually 'defining' what is meant by "IT"(Information Technology).can you suggest some ways to appraoch answering that question?it might loosely be restricted to 'computer technology', but i think that is naive, and would like to expand the scope, if justified.there's a lot of "information" and communication research and products that preceded computers (think Bell Labs).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
